TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP citizen , born in DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG His parents lived together from DATE until DATE . They were not married and , in accordance with NORP law , only the mother had parental rights over the child . After the parents separated in DATE , the applicant remained with the mother and the father had access to him on a " gentlemen ’s agreement " basis . However , this arrangement did not function well and in DATE the father obtained a specific right of access through the competent authorities .

CARDINAL . ORG It appears that a closer relationship developed between the applicant and his father during DATE . The NORP legislation at the time , however , did not provide special procedures for having the custody rights transferred from the mother to the father , and the father introduced an application to ORG ( no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) complaining about his situation on DATE . During the proceedings before the Commission , the Custody and LAW DATE ( myndighedsloven , " LAW " , see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) was amended with effect from DATE , so that a court might vest parental custody in the father of a child born out of wedlock , when certain conditions were fulfilled . As a result the ORG , on DATE , rejected the application on the ground that the father could no longer claim to be a victim of an alleged violation of ORG and Reports no . CARDINAL , pp . CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG The father had regular access to the applicant until DATE , when the applicant apparently refused to return to the mother after a DATE holiday with the father . The social authorities were contacted and , with the consent of all parties , the applicant was placed in a children ’s home . However , he disappeared from the home and returned to the father . On DATE , the father instituted proceedings before ORG of ORG ( ORG ret ) to have the custody rights transferred to him according to the new law . Father and child also went " underground " until DATE , when the father was arrested by the police . He was released on DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , after the father ’s arrest , the social authorities , with the consent of the mother , placed the applicant in ORG in the county hospital , PERSON . On DATE , the father ’s right of access was suspended . The father ’s appeal against this decision was rejected by ORG on DATE . The applicant disappeared from GPE on DATE and thereafter started to live in hiding with his father again .
CARDINAL . ORG In the custody proceedings before ORG of ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , the court held on DATE that a transfer of custody to the father was not in the interest of the child .

CARDINAL . ORG The applicant ’s father appealed against this judgment to ORG for LOC ( PERSON ) . On DATE , the parties agreed that the applicant should undergo a child psychiatric examination by Professor PERSON . This examination resulted in a report of DATE , in which Professor PERSON concluded ( translation from NORP ) :

" After considering the case , I find it in the best interest of the child that the custody rights remain with the mother . Since the boy is developing nervously it is recommended that he and the mother , after [ the applicant ] has returned to her , get child psychiatric support . ... "
On DATE , ORG upheld ORG judgment . The applicant nevertheless remained in hiding with his father , staying with various families in GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG In DATE , after having lived " underground " for DATE , the applicant ’s father again instituted proceedings before ORG of ORG in order to have the custody rights transferred to him . Since he was wanted by the police , on suspicion of having kidnapped the applicant , the father did not attend the hearings in person , but only through his lawyer . Before ORG the applicant ’s mother maintained that the applicant had been harmed due to the abnormal circumstances under which he had lived with his father and that she would accept Professor PERSON ’s recommendation and obtain support from ORG ( den børnepsykiatriske afdeling ) of ORG ( ORG ) , a university and general hospital , for a transitional period ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .
In its judgment of DATE , ORG found that the custody rights .

CARDINAL . ORG The applicant ’s father appealed to ORG , but on DATE ORG upheld ORG judgment . Leave was subsequently granted by ORG to bring the case before ORG ( Højesteret ) ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . Directly after the hearing in ORG on DATE , at which both the father and the applicant were present , the father was arrested by the police and charged with depriving the mother of the exercise of her parental rights in violation of section CARDINAL , read in conjunction with section CARDINAL paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL , of GPE . The applicant was placed in a children ’s home .

CARDINAL . ORG The mother , advised by ORG of GPE and Professor PERSON , and with the recommendation of her family doctor , requested that the applicant , who was by then DATE , be admitted to ORG since it was clear that he did not want to stay with her . On DATE , the applicant was admitted to the Ward by Professor PERSON who was Chief Physician at the LOC . On DATE , ORG recorded its approval , pursuant to section CARDINAL of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , that the applicant was to be placed away from home in accordance with his mother ’s wish .

CARDINAL . ORG According to Professor PERSON , who was responsible for the applicant ’s treatment at ORG , the procedure followed in connection with admission was the usual CARDINAL : the holder of the parental rights made the request , the family doctor recommended admission and the responsible chief physician of the ward accepted to admit the applicant .

CARDINAL . ORG By letter of DATE to ORG , the applicant ’s father , on behalf of the applicant , questioned the lawfulness of the applicant ’s " detention " at ORG contrary to the applicant ’s wish . He maintained , inter alia , that the provisions of the hospitalisation of LAW Act DATE ( Lov om sindssyge personers hospitalsophold , Act no . CARDINAL of DATE , as amended by Act no . CARDINAL of DATE LAW " ; see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) regarding compulsory admission to hospital had not been observed .

ORG submitted the matter to the Chief Physician at ORG . In accordance with the information he gave , the ORG replied , on DATE , that the applicant had not been admitted in accordance with LAW , but on the basis of a decision by his mother as holder of the custody rights , and that it could not make a determination in the matter .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , the applicant ’s representatives nevertheless petitioned ORG ( ORG byret ) under chapter CARDINALa of ORG ( retsplejeloven ) ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) for a decision on the lawfulness of the applicant ’s placement in ORG . The defendant , ORG , pleaded dismissal , maintaining that the applicant had not been subjected to administrative deprivation of liberty under LAW .
CARDINAL . ORG In its judgment of DATE , ORG upheld ORG plea for dismissal on the following grounds ( translation from NORP ) :

" Considering that [ the applicant ] ... has been admitted to ORG of ORG , GPE , on the basis of a decision made by [ his mother ] , who is the holder of parental rights , [ the applicant ’s ] detention at ORG is not covered by the [ DATE ] Act and it is therefore not subject to judicial review according to chapter DATE of ORG . For this very reason the petition must be dismissed . "

CARDINAL . ORG The applicant appealed , through the father , to ORG arguing , in particular , that if he had not been a minor he could have challenged the lawfulness of his detention in ORG before the courts . He added that , although the holder of the custody rights had , according to section CARDINAL of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , an extensive right to make decisions concerning the child , such a right should be subject to certain restrictions ; a totally involuntary detention ought to be an interference which could only be carried out administratively and thus under the conditions mentioned in LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , irrespective of any decision by his mother .

The ORG Attorney ( Kammeradvokaten ) again maintained that the case did not concern administrative deprivation of liberty and was thus outside the scope of chapter DATE of ORG . In the alternative he alleged that , if the case disclosed deprivation of liberty within the meaning of chapter DATE , the father would be unable to act on behalf of the child since at that time he had no , and had never had any , parental rights over the child .
CARDINAL . ORG Rejecting the ORG Attorney ’s latter argument , ORG stated in its judgment of DATE ( translation from NORP ) :

" The question whether a minor should be subjected to treatment in a hospital is normally decided by the holder of parental rights and such measures can not be challenged by means of chapter CARDINALa of ORG .

Concerning the treatment of mentally deranged persons , inter alia in public hospitals , special rules apply according to the [ CARDINAL Act ] , cf . chapter CARDINALa of ORG . From what has been established in this case it appears that [ the applicant ] does not suffer from any mental illness and according to the above there has been no question of admittance for treatment of a mental illness . The decision to admit [ the applicant ] to ORG of ORG after the disturbances he has been through and the decision on his temporary stay there were taken by his mother , who has the parental rights over him . The appellant ’s claim for judicial review DATE can not therefore be granted and the decision of ORG to dismiss the case is upheld . "

CARDINAL . ORG The applicant ’s representatives asked ORG , according to section CARDINAL of ORG , for leave to appeal to ORG . However , on DATE the ORG refused leave since ORG was of the opinion that the judgment would not be overruled by ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , PERSON , as representative of the father , also sent copies of the complaints to ORG to ORG , an authority under ORG ) . On DATE , he requested that this authority carry out an investigation of whether the applicant was forced to visit his mother and whether Professor PERSON could lawfully prevent him from visiting the applicant . ORG found the legal issues raised by the father to be beyond its authority , but decided nevertheless , on its own account , to take up the question of how the applicant had been treated from a medical point of view .

CARDINAL . ORG In the course of ORG investigation Professor PERSON submitted , on DATE , the following report regarding the circumstances of the applicant ’s stay at ORG to ORG of GPE ( PERSON ) ( translation from NORP ) :

" [ The applicant ] has expressed his dislike of staying here , but at no time has he attempted to run away . We have not been able and have not wanted to prevent him from running away , which he could have done , inter alia , when he left the Ward together with the other children , e.g. to visit museums or to go for a hair cut . Also in this respect he has been in hospital on the same terms as the other patients of the Ward .
The treatment involves environmental therapy at the LOC and regular talks with [ the applicant ] .
At no time has he been given treatment involving medication .

Since DATE , his mother has visited the ORG regularly during the usual visiting TIME on DATE and DATE . Since DATE [ the applicant ] has visited his mother at home . The visits were at first short , but since DATE he has been able to spend the weekends there . DATE were spent with his mother and so was New Year ’s Day .

I wish to add that the patients at the LOC are not ‘ compulsorily ORG in the usual sense of the expression in [ LAW ] . ORG of ORG is an ordinary hospital ward run in principle on the same conditions as the other wards of ORG . As the LOC is situated on the seventh floor in a building with a number of somatic wards , the main entrance of each block has a latch ( smæklås ) to prevent the children of the ward , some of whom may be inclined to rush around impulsively , from running about in the hospital or running into town , and possibly being a nuisance to the patients in other wards of the hospital or exposing themselves to danger . This measure is to be compared with the locked front door in a family house . As mentioned above , the children often go out with the staff , e.g. to playgrounds or to visit museums . During their stay in hospital the children are not normally confined to bed , and the LOC offers many possibilities for different activities under homelike conditions . Thus it is entirely misleading ... to talk about ‘ institutional detention’ . "
The treatment given to the applicant at the ORG was explained in more detail by Professor PERSON in a report to ORG on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) ( translation from NORP ) :

" The treatment consisted of environmental therapy and individual talks . In the environmental treatment endeavours were made to let him experience relaxed , homelike surroundings together with adults who were neutral in relation to the previous conflicts concerning custody . ORG were also made to protect him from pressure by the media , which however could not be completely averted , because when he went outside the LOC he could read the headlines of the newspapers , and through a completely free and very extensive correspondence he could follow the media reports . As a whole , PERSON seemed to be happy and secure in the LOC , and the objective of the environment therapy had been largely achieved at the time of discharge . However , at that time PERSON had a continued need for ambulatory therapy of individual talks . "
In his report , Professor PERSON also pointed out that the applicant had been allowed to pay visits to his father in prison DATE since DATE ( in total CARDINAL such visits took place ) .
CARDINAL . ORG The applicant ’s development in the course of his treatment at the LOC was described by Professor PERSON in a report on DATE to ORG of GPE ( translation from NORP ) :

" ... During the treatment , including the environmental therapy and the personal talks , at ORG since New Year CARDINAL , [ the applicant ] has continued to grow more relaxed , more extrovert and spontaneous and he is now able to show his feelings better . This applies to his relationships both with the staff and with the other children in the LOC . During the entire stay at the hospital he has as before , apart from DATE , been allowed to move about freely just like the other children . In other words , he has gone to the library on his own , has joined visits to museums in town , been to the swimming pool , skating rink , etc .

His relationship with his mother also underwent a similar favourable development in the same period . He saw his mother DATE and participated in the family life together with his mother , her friend , and his sister . At first he was a bit shy to leave his home , apparently for fear of being recognised . On DATE , he started school again in his old class , and the Ward prepared his return together with the school . He has taken up contact with his old school mates when visiting his mother during DATE . In connection with the school ’s DATE , he had his longest stay with his mother from DATE until DATE . During DATE , the whole family went for DATE to his mother ’s parents in GPE . It was obvious that [ the applicant ] enjoyed this family outing ... "
CARDINAL . ORG As part of ORG investigation ORG of ORG was also requested to visit the ward in which the applicant was placed . In her report of CARDINAL DATE , she stated ( translation from NORP ) :
" The Child Psychiatric Ward currently keeps CARDINAL children in continuous treatment , the average period of therapy being DATE .

[ The applicant ] was not at home while I was there but in school . During DATE , he has been attending the same elementary school he used to go to and where he apparently feels at ease . DATE he goes to and from the school by cab , alone .

Much is done to make the children feel at home . [ The applicant ] takes swimming lessons together with other children in the LOC accompanied by CARDINAL of the staff members . He has also gone sledge riding and may visit school friends . The entrance door to all children ’s wards is locked , partly to prevent the young children from running all over the hospital LOC where they might hurt themselves in lifts or lose their way . The entrance door is locked also in order to minimise the substantial risk of theft .
[ The applicant ] is allowed to leave the Ward if he asks for permission to go , for instance , to the library . He moves around unaccompanied on these occasions .

My conclusion is that [ the applicant ] is staying in an environment as similar as possible to a real home and that he is by no means kept there against his will . On the contrary , he is allowed to move about outside the LOC all by himself or in the company of staff members and/or other children ... "
CARDINAL . ORG In its final report of CARDINAL DATE , ORG concluded ( translation from NORP ) :

" On the present material ORG does not find any reason for not approving Professor PERSON ’s medical evaluation the essence of which was that [ the applicant ] was trapped in a neurotic state requiring treatment , a development which the ORG views as the result of the most unusual circumstances in which [ the applicant ] had been living with his father during DATE . If these circumstances had continued , the risk of a further move towards a personality - stunting , chronically neurotic state of mind would , in the opinion of the ORG , have been extremely likely .

Nor does ORG see any reason for criticising the medical treatment which [ the applicant ] received while hospitalised and which was designed to integrate him in normal human relationships ... , and included talks at regular intervals with [ the applicant ] and his mother , since the ORG , things being what they were , would find it irreconcilable with the welfare of [ the applicant ] to deny him relevant treatment . According to the information available to the ORG , [ the applicant ] is now so well that he may probably be discharged by DATE . By then , the period of his hospitalisation will not have exceeded the average period . While hospitalised [ the applicant ] has been allowed to visit his father regularly at FAC [ prison ] .
To sum up : ORG sees no reason for criticising Professor PERSON or ORG of ORG for their medical treatment of [ the applicant ] . "
CARDINAL . ORG The applicant has not repudiated the above statements ( see paragraphs DATE ) . However his representative has added before the Commission that :

" The Child Psychiatric Ward is definitely a closed ward . The door to the Ward was locked and [ the applicant ] was totally unable to receive visitors except with the agreement and under the surveillance of the staff at the Ward ... [ The applicant ] was unable to leave the hospital if he so wished . ...

[ He ] was not permitted to phone [ his father ’s counsel ] or his father , who was in prison charged with the kidnapping of the applicant , who had actually been the active party in the kidnapping . [ The applicant ] was under almost constant surveillance : he was unable to make social contacts ; persons from outside the hospital were unable to get in contact with him without special permission ... "

CARDINAL . ORG According to information submitted by the Government in response to a request by ORG , no children had ever been admitted under the compulsory procedure in LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) to the ward in which the applicant was placed and this ward had never had any patients suffering from mental illnesses of a psychotic nature .

CARDINAL . ORG It was planned that the applicant should be discharged to his mother ’s home on DATE . However , on DATE he disappeared from the hospital . His mother reported the disappearance to the police . On DATE , the police found the applicant , who had stayed with various families in GPE , and brought him back to ORG in GPE where he was readmitted to ORG at his mother ’s request .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , the father , who had been detained on remand since his arrest on CARDINAL DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , was sentenced to CARDINAL months’ imprisonment by ORG . Having regard to the time spent in detention on remand , he was released on DATE .
CARDINAL . ORG The applicant was discharged from the hospital on DATE and placed in the care of a family not officially known to the father .

CARDINAL . ORG The question whether to transfer the custody rights from the mother to the father was , as mentioned above ( see paragraph CARDINAL ) , brought before ORG following the decision of ORG on DATE . Before ORG Professor PERSON maintained , in a report of DATE , that it would be in the best interest of the applicant that the parental rights remained with his mother . This opinion was supported by ORG ( Retslægerådet ) in a statement of CARDINAL DATE . However , on DATE ORG , by a majority of CARDINAL votes to CARDINAL , overruled ORG decisions and awarded custody of the applicant to his father . The majority in their judgment said ( translation from NORP ) :

" The respondent [ the mother ] must be considered well suited to exercise custody and there seems to be no reason to believe that the appellant [ the father ] should not be suited to handle this task . As the desirability of continued child - psychiatric support is not found to counterbalance the need for a decision now on the question as to which parent PERSON is to reside with , these judges find that out of consideration for his welfare it is desirable that custody of him be granted to the appellant in accordance with PERSON ’s own wish , regardless of whether his attitude to his parents may be due to a CARDINAL - sided influence during his stay with the appellant . Their decision is therefore to find for the appellant . "
The applicant now lives with his father .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW ( PERSON ) protects the right to personal liberty . Under paragraph CARDINAL deprivations of liberty outside criminal procedure , not executed by order of a judicial authority and not warranted by legislation relating to aliens , are made subject to judicial review .

CARDINAL . ORG LAW of ORG deals with judicial review of administrative deprivations of liberty . Its introductory section CARDINAL states that , unless otherwise provided by statute , its provisions apply only to detentions outside criminal procedure not executed by order of a judicial authority .

CARDINAL . ORG The NORP rules on parental custody are laid down in the Custody and LAW Act DATE ( myndighedsloven , Act No . CARDINAL of DATE - " LAW " ) . According to this LAW , children and young persons DATE are under parental custody unless they have contracted marriage .
The holder of the parental rights has , according to section DATE , a duty to provide for the care and welfare of the child and has power to take decisions on the personal life of the child .

Parental rights over children born out of wedlock are , according to CARDINAL , vested in the mother . Under that section , as amended in DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , they may however be transferred to the father where required out of special regard for the welfare of the child .

CARDINAL . ORG At the relevant time , the LAW contained no provisions on the child ’s participation in decision - making concerning the child ’s personal life . On DATE it was amended ( Act No . CARDINAL ) and , according to a new section CARDINAL and section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL , any minor who has attained DATE is normally to be heard before a decision on custody , access rights or appointment of a guardian is made . The hearing of the child may however be omitted if it can be assumed to be unnecessary or harmful to the child .
CARDINAL . ORG According to section CARDINAL of LAW DATE ( PERSON om social bistand , Act No . CARDINAL of DATE ) ( translation from NORP ) :

" Any person who becomes aware that a child or a young person DATE is exposed to neglect or degrading treatment on the part of the parents or other educators or lives under conditions liable to imperil his health or development shall be under a duty to notify the local social welfare committee . "

CARDINAL . ORG According to section DATE it shall be the duty of the local social welfare committee to supervise the conditions under which the children within its area live and to support their parents in their upbringing and care . Sub - section CARDINAL specifies that the committee shall give the holder of the parental rights or the person who in actual fact takes care of the child special guidance and support if the child has difficulties in relation to his environment , his school or the community , or if the child is otherwise living under unsatisfactory conditions .

CARDINAL . ORG In the context of its advisory and supervisory duties under LAW , the local social welfare committee may , according to section DATE , " as far as possible in cooperation with the child and his home " , inter alia " provide for the child to be placed away from home " where such a supportive measure is " required in the interests of the child , cf . section CARDINAL , sub - section CARDINAL " .

CARDINAL . ORG According to the LAW , the social welfare authorities may however have to provide supportive measures even in the absence of consent from the holder of parental rights . Section CARDINAL specifies ( translation from NORP ) :

" [ CARDINAL ] Where absolutely necessary in the interests of the welfare of the child , the local social welfare committee may , until the child attains the age of CARDINAL , without the consent of the person having the parental rights over the child , decide
( i ) to remove the child from his home ;

( ii ) to commit the child to the psychiatric department of a hospital or to a mental hospital with the acceptance of the chief physician of the hospital , even though the general conditions prescribed in the legislation on the hospitalisation of mentally ill persons are not satisfied ;

( iii ) to refuse to let the child return home or place the child elsewhere , notwithstanding the fact that the initial care was established with the consent of the person having the parental rights over the child .

( CARDINAL ) Where the supportive measures according to sub - section CARDINAL have exceeded CARDINAL year , the local social welfare committee shall reconsider the case . Where the young person is DATE , the supportive measures can only be maintained with his or her consent . "

Before a decision under this section is taken , the holder of the parental rights , the guardian , the child , the attorney and any other adviser shall , according to LAW , have the opportunity to make a statement to the local social welfare committee .

CARDINAL . ORG A decision to remove the child from his home under LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) can , according to section CARDINAL , be appealed against to ORG by the person who has parental rights over the child , the person who in actual fact exercises those rights or , if the matter relates to a person who is not subject to parental authority , the young person himself or his guardian .
These persons may also , under section CARDINAL , have the decision of ORG brought before ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG According to section CARDINAL of the hospitalisation of LAW DATE , a patient can only be committed to a mental hospital on a written medical recommendation based on a medical examination made within DATE before the committal . Apart from patients who are admitted at their own request , the medical recommendation shall be made by a medical practitioner who is not an employee of the mental hospital .
CARDINAL . ORG The responsible chief physician shall decide , pursuant to LAW , whether the conditions for committal are fulfilled and whether the patient shall be treated for his illness .

CARDINAL . ORG According to section CARDINAL , a discharge may be requested by the patient himself or the following persons : the holder of the parental rights , the guardian , the trustee , the husband or wife , a son or daughter if of age , the father or mother , or another close relative .
Where discharge is refused by the responsible medical officer , the person making the request can bring the case before the Minister of ORG .

If the Minister of ORG also refuses the discharge , the person who made the request shall be advised that judicial review of the lawfulness of the detention may be sought in accordance with chapter PERSON of ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . ORG The situations in which the responsible medical officer may refuse a discharge are set out in LAW . These are either that the patient is dangerous to himself or others , or that the discharge would considerably reduce the prospects for the patient ’s recovery . Outside these situations a discharge may be refused only if it must be presumed to cause considerable disadvantages for the patient himself and ORG endorses the refusal .

Where discharge has been refused by the Minister of ORG , the issue of discharge may not be raised again within a period of DATE either from the date of the Minister of ORG ’s decision or , where the issue of lawfulness has been brought before a court , from the date of the court ’s decision .

CARDINAL . ORG In DATE ORG appointed a committee to consider possible amendments to LAW ( see paragraphs CARDINAL above ) , in particular with regard to the use of compulsion . The committee was composed of legal and medical experts as well as representatives of ORG organisations . In DATE , the committee published ORG on the Principles on DATE in ORG " ( Principbetænkning om tvang i psykiatrien , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . ORG The existing legal situation in respect of admission to hospital of minors not suffering from mental illnesses covered by LAW was described as follows ( translation from NORP ) :

" The holder of the parental rights shall , inter alia , provide the required medical treatment for the child and can in this connection decide where the child shall stay , if need be in a hospital , provided , of course , that the hospital accedes to the request for admission . Admission to a hospital of a child for treatment of physical disorders presents no problems . The holder of the parental rights can with the consent of the medical officer decide on admission to a hospital and detention there , notwithstanding the protests of the child , and the child has no possibility of having tried whether the admission to the hospital and the detention there were justified since this decision rests solely with the holder of the parental rights . To say that the medical doctor , who admits or receives the child into the hospital , by complying with the request of the holder of the parental rights , has made a decision which the child itself may request to be reviewed in court would be meaningless , as indirectly it would constitute an interference with the statutory right of the holder of the parental rights to make decisions , within the limits of the law , on the personal life of the child . The control required is here exercised by the medical officer admitting the child to the hospital or by the hospital doctors , who , as we know , will oppose any unnecessary hospitalisation of minors . Up till now there have been no unpleasant experiences in practice which can justify a possible legal adjustment of the right of parents to have their children hospitalised for treatment of physical disorders .

Where a child is admitted to hospital to be treated for mental disorders , the legal position is described in CARDINAL B above [ section dealing with the situation under LAW , not reproduced here ] , provided that a child is involved here whose opinion will have to be considered and who is admitted as mentally ill . This implies that the exercise of the powers inherent in parental custody must give way to the [ CARDINAL Act ] with the effect that the parents can not per se decide that the minor shall be hospitalised contrary to his wishes , and that the parents can not , on the other hand , have the minor discharged if the chief physician finds that the conditions for compulsory detention have been fulfilled .

The problem arises , however , where the child is hospitalised to be treated for a mental disorder of a non - psychotic nature . Since only mentally ill persons are covered by the [ CARDINAL Act ] , this LAW can not be expected to restrict the exercise of parental rights in these cases . It is therefore natural to treat on the same legal footing as physical disorders , mental disorders other than psychoses , with the consequence that the decision of the holder of the parental rights prevails , provided that the chief physician can justify the hospitalisation of the child for treatment . " ( pp . CARDINAL of the report )

" Here [ i.e. in the case of mental disorders outside the scope of LAW ] , the protection of the child - as in the case of physical disorders - is to be sought in the fact that the medical officer under professional responsibility must assess whether the request made by the holder of the parental rights for admission to a hospital can be considered justified . " ( p. CARDINAL of the report )
The report did not suggest any changes to the existing legal situation described above .
